#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|

#Text=Under pressure: assessment of chemical stress on restored river sections using effect_based methods.

#Text=Sarah Hoerchner,�Ariane Moulinec,�Andrea Sundermann,�Joerg Oehlmann,�Matthias Oetken\rFirst published: 29 May 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14206\rAuthor contributions: SH, AM, AS, MO conceived and designed the research; SH, AM performed the field work; SH performed ecotoxicological study; AM performed ecological study; SH, AM analyzed and visualized data; SH wrote the first draft; SH, AM, AS, JO, MO revised and edited the manuscript; AS, MO acquired funding.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Stephen Murphy\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract,\rAquatic ecosystems are affected by multiple stressors, including hydrological and morphological degradation, high nutrient loading, and chemical pollution.
#Text=To improve freshwater habitats, hydromorphological restorations have been increasingly implemented.
#Text=However, follow_up assessments often show little to no improvement in ecological status, even years after restoration measures have been implemented.
#Text=The success of restoration projects can be compromised by other stressors, such as insufficient water and sediment quality, which often receive less attention compared to nonchemical stressors.
#Text=In this study, the impact of chemical stress on the outcome of five river restorations was evaluated ecologically, chemically, and ecotoxicologically.
#Text=Overall, the habitat structure was considerably improved through the restoration measures, whereas the species communities did not show a consistent trend toward an improved ecological status.
#Text=Effect_based methods were used for an integrative assessment of the exposure to chemical mixtures in water and sediment samples of restored stream sections.
#Text=Differences in toxicity between restored and non_restored sections were found but did not show a consistent trend among the applied assays.

#Text=In contrast, the chemical analysis showed that the sections of the same stream were similar in their chemical composition, and differences within a stream were primarily due to sediment contamination.

#Text=The results of this study suggest that chemical pollution is a relevant factor preventing the success of restoration measures and, ultimately, the improvement of the ecological status of rivers.
#Text=They also demonstrate the applicability of EBMs in water quality monitoring to detect mixture toxicity in streams and link chemical and ecological assessment.
#Text=Implications for Practice,\r* To maintain or restore the good ecological status of surface waters, an integrated approach is required.

#Text=This approach should take into account the complex interactions between different stressors, such as hydromorphological changes and chemical pollution, and integrate them into the planning and implementation of measures.\r* Effect_based assessment of water bodies is essential to adequately consider the effects of chemical pollution on aquatic organisms, considering the toxicities we found in water and sediments.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=The loss of biodiversity is one of the biggest issues of our time.
#Text=Freshwater ecosystems in particular are among the most altered ecosystems and show a disproportionate amount of biodiversity loss (Eastwood et al�2023).

#Text=Rivers and streams are affected by multiple stressors, including hydrological and morphological degradation, high nutrient loading, raised temperatures, and chemical pollution originating from anthropogenic activities (Voeroesmarty et al�2010; Piggott et al�2012).

#Text=To tackle the issue of structural degradation, hydromorphological restorations have been increasingly implemented as a key measure to improve freshwater habitats and thus the ecological status of water bodies (Haase et al�2013; Palmer et al�2014; Muhar et al�2016).

#Text=Ideally, this leads to greater structural diversity, allowing species to return to and recolonize restored river sections (S�ndergaard & Jeppesen�2007; Theodoropoulos et al�2020; Li et al�2022).

#Text=However, follow_up assessments often show little to no improvement in ecological status even years after restoration measures have been implemented (Sundermann et al�2011; Palmer et al�2014; Friberg et al�2016).
#Text=Recovery of aquatic biota, especially benthic invertebrate communities, does not develop toward a future equilibrium in a linear fashion (Brettschneider et al�2023).
#Text=Instead, their development is affected by various stress factors.
#Text=These stressors can superimpose on hydromorphological degradation and compromise the success of restoration projects (Sundermann et al�2013; Carvalho et al�2019; Li et al�2022).
#Text=This is especially the case for pollutant input from diffuse and point sources (Sundermann et al�2013; Posthuma et al�2020; Enns et al�2023).

#Text=Here, micropollutants, including pesticides, industrial compounds, pharmaceuticals, personal care products, steroid hormones, and nutrients, are discharged into rivers through industrial and domestic wastewater, as well as agricultural run_off (Barbosa et al�2016; Brack et al�2017).
#Text=Consequently, mixtures of over 200,000 commercially available chemicals can potentially enter water bodies (Finckh et al�2022).

#Text=Yet, only a small fraction of chemicals are considered in standardized monitoring programs when assessing the effects of chemical pollution on water quality by using chemical target analyses, while the effects of individual chemicals and, more importantly, their complex mixtures on organisms and communities are ignored (Posthuma et al�2019; Finckh et al�2022).
#Text=There is growing evidence that the toxicity of such mixtures is underestimated (Kortenkamp et al�2019; Shao et al�2019).

#Text=This highlights the insufficient linkage between chemical pollution as a stressor and ecosystem impacts in monitoring and assessment (Posthuma et al�2020; Lemm et al�2021) and the disconnection between ecology, (eco)toxicology, and chemistry (Sylvester et al�2023).
#Text=Hydromorphological restoration measures are not only quite ineffective in improving the ecological status of water bodies but may even lead to a deterioration of the local pollution situation.

#Text=Brettschneider et al (2019) showed that in rivers with a high proportion of treated wastewater, hydromorphological restoration not only failed to improve the ecological status, but in the restored sections a higher toxicity than in the non_restored control sections of the same river was found.

#Text=Generally, the extent to which water pollution affects the recovery of aquatic communities in morphologically restored river sections is hardly studied, difficult to predict, and predictions are potentially misleading using current monitoring methods (Posthuma et al�2020; Escher et al�2021; He� et al�2023).
#Text=Consequently, the implementation of a scientifically sound and target_oriented monitoring approach is mandatory.
#Text=For this purpose, effect_based methods (EBMs) are recommended to gain better insight into the impact of pollutants and their underlying mechanisms (Brack et al�2017; Altenburger et al�2019).
#Text=EBMs refer to in vitro and in vivo investigations at the sub_organismic and organismic levels.

#Text=By assessing the mixture toxicity of all ecotoxicologically effective substances, a realistic picture of the load of pollutants in the water body can be depicted (Di Paolo et al�2016; Neale et al�2020; Escher et al�2021).
#Text=In this study, the effects of river restorations on the chemical stress level and on the macroinvertebrate communities were assessed.
#Text=For this end, we compared benthic macroinvertebrate assemblages and the morphological status of restored and nearby non_restored sections in five rivers.
#Text=Moreover, we investigated these sections using EBMs, as described in Brettschneider et al (2019).
#Text=In addition, we performed chemical analyses in water and sediment samples.

#Text=We aimed to determine (1) whether the restored river sections have improved morphology compared to the non_restored control sections, which is the prerequisite for higher biodiversity; (2) whether there is an improvement in the ecological status class; (3) whether there is a difference in toxicity and chemical composition between restored and non_restored river sections; and (4) if water pollution is a factor that causes the failure to achieve good ecological status.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Site.

#Text=Our survey included five hydromorphological river restoration projects located in Hesse, Germany (Fig�1), at the rivers Asphe (A), Bieber (B), Fohnbach (F), Josbach (J), and W�rf (W), belonging to stream types 5 (coarse material_rich, silicate low mountain streams: A, B, F) and 5.1 (fine material_rich, silicate low mountain streams: J, W), according to Pottgiesser (2018).
#Text=The rivers cover a catchment area of 13.5_34.6 km2.

#Text=The river restoration projects were selected for having undergone comprehensive hydromorphological restoration measures that are common techniques in central European restoration practices (for details, see Table�1).

#Text=The length of the restored river section was at least 1100 m and the restoration age (time period between completion and sampling) ranged from 13 to 29 years, with a mean restoration age of 20.2 years.
#Text=The focus was deliberately on measures that were implemented several years ago in order to give the organisms the necessary time to repopulate.

#Text=Within the river restoration project, a restored section was selected for investigation and a second non_restored section was chosen in the same river, which was 550_1270 m upstream of the restored section.

#Text=The non_restored sections were carefully selected to represent the pre_restoration status of the restored sections in terms of stream type, stream order, water quality, and local land use patterns: No confluences of tributaries, point source discharges, lakes, fishponds, or impoundment basins were between the two sections.
#Text=Figure 1\rMap of the investigated non_restored and restored river sections of sampling Sites A (Asphe), B (Bieber), F (Fohnbach), J (Josbach), and W (W�rf) with land use classes.
#Text=The map was created using QGIS, v. 3.28.10.
#Text=Table 1.

#Text=�Characterization of the sampling sites, with geographical coordinates, distance between the stream sections sampled, stream type according to Pottgiesser (2018), length of the restored sections, age of the projects and details of the measures.

#Text=Stream name\rStream section\rShort name\rStream section coordinates\rDistance between stream sections (m)\rStream type\rLength of restoration (m)\rTime since restoration (years)\rRestoration measure\rAsphe\rNon_restored\rA_nr\r50.92908765\r8.678383997\r970\r5\r1100\r29\rElevation of the riverbed; weir deconstruction; installation of structural elements\r\rRestored\rA_r\r50.92194956\r8.683498811\r\r\r\r\r\rBieber\rNon_restored\rB_nr\r50.60311089\r8.616097262\r1250\r5\r1600\r13\rCreation of stillwater zones; securing of floodplain forest succession; removal of riverbed and bank protections\r\rRestored\rB_r\r50.59441505\r8.627442776\r\r\r\r\r\rFohnbach\rNon_restored\rF_nr\r50.59186918\r8.635267422\r1050\r5\r1600\r20\rCreating a secondary riparian zone; leaving near_natural structural elements and bank breaks; increase the structural diversity; removal of non_natural bed and bank stabilization\r\rRestored\rF_r\r50.58579928\r8.643162987\r\r\r\r\r\rJosbach\rNon_restored\rJ_nr\r50.91193326\r8.980424916\r550\r5.1\r1900\r29\rIntroduction of riparian wood stream bed elevation; natural stream development; reconnection of the floodplain\r\rRestored\rJ_r\r50.91239585\r8.973452758\r\r\r\r\r\rW�rf\rNon_restored\rW_nr\r50.7973178\r8.849401033\r1270\r5.1\r3700\r19\rIntroduction of wood and bedrock; construction of riffle/pool sequences; creation of steep and shallow bank areas; support of riparian vegetation; development of floodplain structures\r\rRestored\rW_r\r50.80496166\r8.861570526\r\r\r\r\r\rBenthic Invertebrate Assemblages.

#Text=Benthic invertebrates were sampled once, either in March or April 2022 according to the sampling protocol for river monitoring programs for assessing the ecological status of river sites in Germany.
#Text=Samples of restored and non_restored sections were taken on the same day by the same person at each site.
#Text=Sample material was sorted in the laboratory following the protocol of Haase et al (2004) and identification followed Haase et al (2006).

#Text=The general degradation of the macroinvertebrates communities was evaluated by multimeric index (MMI) and attributed to ecological classes as defined in Boehmer et al (2004) (for a detailed description, see Supplement�S1).
#Text=Evaluation of Local Scale Habitat Structure.

#Text=The river habitat survey method of Bund/L�nder_Arbeitsgemeinschaft Wasser (Kamp et al�2007) was used to assess the small_scale habitat structure of a site, as described in Sundermann et al (2013).

#Text=It distinguishes six hydromorphological indices (channel development, longitudinal profile, bed structures, cross profile, bank structure, and adjacent land zone) and evaluates their degree of change compared to natural conditions.
#Text=Each variable in the six categories can take a decimal scoring index value ranging from 1 (undisturbed) to 7 (totally disturbed) (Table�S1).
#Text=Sampling of Water and Sediments\rThe sampling campaign included water and sediment sampling during the dry summer period (May_June 2022).
#Text=Water\rFor in vitro analyses, water samples were taken in ultra violet_protected 1_L amber glass bottles.
#Text=The glass vessels were cleaned previously with acetone, ethanol, and deionized water and heated to 200 degrees C in a drying oven (VWR International GmbH, Darmstadt, Germany).
#Text=Samples were stored at 4 degrees C for a maximum of 24 hours until further processing.

#Text=For the in vivo experiments with�Potamopyrgus antipodarum�(New Zealand mudsnail), additional weekly aqueous grab samples were collected from each sampling site and stored at 4 degrees C for 24 hours until further use.
#Text=Chemical and physical parameters (temperature, pH, conductivity, oxygen concentration, and flow velocity) were measured in situ (Hach Lange GmbH, D�sseldorf, Germany).

#Text=The concentrations of ammonium, nitrite, nitrate, and phosphate were quantified in the laboratory with a spectral photometer (Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany) using rapid analytical tests (Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany).
#Text=The extracts for ecotoxicological testing were enriched from 1 L of the native sample that was filtered through a 1.5  m glass_microfiber filter (VWR International GmbH, Darmstadt, Germany).
#Text=Subsequently, a solid_phase extraction was performed according to Giebner et al (2018) using Oasis HLB cartridges (200 mg, Waters, Milford, MA, U.S.A.).
#Text=These cartridges were eluted using methyl_tert_butyl_ether and methanol (4 mL each).
#Text=Both solvents were evaporated under a gentle stream of nitrogen and finally dissolved in 200  L dimethyl_sulfoxide (DMSO), resulting in 5000_fold enriched extracts.

#Text=Sediments\rSediment samples were taken from the near surface layer (first 5_10 cm) at each sampling site in the cross and longitudinal profiles and combined to create a single representative grab sediment sample for each sampling point.
#Text=Sediment samples were stored in freezer bags and frozen at  23 degrees C until further processing.
#Text=For the in vivo experiments with�Potamopyrgus antipodarum, native sediment was tested, with aliquots sieved to 2 mm and frozen at  23 degrees C in darkness until use.
#Text=For the other bioassays, sediment extracts were tested.
#Text=Before extraction, frozen sediment samples were freeze_dried (Martin Christ Freeze_drying Systems GmbH, Osterode, Germany) and later sieved to 2 mm and homogenized.
#Text=Dried and sieved sediment samples were stored at 4 degrees C in darkness until extraction.
#Text=Sediment aliquots of 10 g dry weight (dw) were extracted using methanol.

#Text=Therefore, sediment samples were dissolved in 40 mL of methanol for 1 hour at 210 rpm (GFL 3017 Orbital Shaker Sch�ttler, Burgwedel, Germany) and then put in an ultrasonic bath (Ultrasonic cleaning unit SONOREX SUPER RK 510 H, Berlin, Germany) for 10 minutes.

#Text=Subsequently, the samples were centrifuged for 5 minutes at 4400 rpm (Eppendorf SE, Hamburg, Germany), filtered through a glass_microfiber filter (VWR International GmbH, Darmstadt, Germany) and evaporated at 65 degrees C using a rotary evaporator (Heidolph Instruments GmbH & Co.
#Text=KG, Schwabach, Germany; VWR International GmbH, Darmstadt, Germany) to approximately 100_200  L.
#Text=Afterward, 500  L of DMSO was added, and the substrate was reduced to a volume of 500  L under gentle nitrogen steam.
#Text=Sediment concentrations were expressed as sediment equivalents (SEQ).
#Text=Thus, the final concentrations of sediment extracts resulted in 20 g SEQ dw mL 1�DMSO.
#Text=In addition, the mean grain size (EN ISO�2018) and the loss on ignition (EN�2021) were determined in sediment samples from each sampling site (see Table�S3).
#Text=Chemical Monitoring.

#Text=For water samples, a total of 91 compounds (pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and heavy metals) were analyzed and for sediment samples, a total of 24 compounds (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons [PAHs] and heavy metals) were analyzed as described in Supplement�S2.
#Text=Bioassays.

#Text=The effects of water and sediment extracts on organisms of different trophic levels were tested in eight bioassays (for a detailed description, see Supplement�S3): Nonspecific toxicity was analyzed using the Microtox assay according to ISO 11348_3 (ISO�2007a), modified as previously described in Voelker et al (2017).

#Text=Mechanism_specific assays evaluated estrogenicity (YES�Yeast estrogen screen) (Giebner et al�2018), dioxin_like activity (YDS�Yeast dioxin screen) (Stalter et al�2011), mutagenicity (Ames fluctuation assay) (ISO�2012), and oxidative stress response (AREc32 assay) (Escher et al�2012; Voelker et al�2017).

#Text=On an organismic level, mortality and morphological effects in�Danio rerio�(zebrafish) embryos (FET�Fish embryo toxicity test) (ISO�2007b), mortality and reprotoxic effects in�P. antipodarum(Brettschneider et al�2019), and survival of�Hyalella azteca�(amphipod) (USEPA�2000) were assessed.
#Text=Data Analysis\rBioanalytical Analysis.
#Text=To determine the half maximal effective concentration or lethal concentration (EC50�or LC50, respectively), a nonlinear regression was performed using a four_parameter logistic function.
#Text=Microtox results were expressed as EC50, as described in Voelker et al (2017).

#Text=The nontoxic limit was calculated by taking the mean EC50�value of all samples between inhibition percentages of 18 and 20 and adding a safety factor of the standard deviation multiplied by 1.96.

#Text=In the yeast reporter gene screens, the measured activities were expressed as equivalent concentrations of 17 _estradiol (E2_Eq) in the YES and of  _naphthoflavone ( _NF_Eq) in the YDS, as described in Wagner and Oehlmann (2009).
#Text=The limit of detection (LOD) of each experiment was calculated as three times the standard deviation of the pooled negative and solvent controls.
#Text=Samples showing an effect greater than LOD were considered active in the respective in vitro assay.
#Text=Mutagenicity in the Ames fluctuation assay was expressed as percentage revertants.
#Text=Wells with an optical density less than 0.6 were considered revertant wells.
#Text=Samples that exceeded 20.8% revertants in two independent experiments after subtracting the historical negative control were considered mutagenic.
#Text=In the AREc32 assay, cell viability and Nrf2 induction were assessed according to Escher et al (2012) and Voelker et al (2017).
#Text=Statistical Analyses.

#Text=Statistical analyses were conducted with the software Microsoft Excel 2016 (Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, WA, U.S.A.), GraphPad Prism, v. 10.01 (GraphPad Software Inc., San Diego, CA, U.S.A.) and R version 4.3.1 (R Core Team�2018) to compare non_restored and restored sections of the same stream.

#Text=Habitat structure indices were tested for normality with a Shapiro_Wilk test to later conduct a two_way repeated measure analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by a pairwise comparison�t�test with the rstatix package (Kassambara�2023).
#Text=In vitro data (Microtox, YES, YDS, and AREc32) was tested for normal distribution using the D'Agostino_Pearson test or Shapiro_Wilk test (n >8).
#Text=The unpaired�ttest was applied for normally distributed data and in case of unequal variances, Welch's correction was used.
#Text=In the case of non_normally distributed data, the Mann_Whitney test (Ttest) was used.
#Text=For in vivo data, embryo counts (P. antipodarum) were tested for significant differences from the control group using a Kruskal_Wallis test, followed by Dunn's post hoc test.

#Text=In addition, differences in mortality between the non_restored and restored sections in the chronic test with�P. antipodarum�and embryo_toxic effects in�D. rerio�were assessed using Fisher's exact test.
#Text=Differences in embryo counts were assessed as already described for in vitro data.
#Text=The statistical significance level was set to�p�less than 0.05.
#Text=To compare the LC50values (H. azteca), we performed a comparison of the 95% confidence intervals (95% CI).
#Text=If the 95% CI did not overlap, we would interprete this as a significant difference between the LC50�values.

#Text=A principal component analysis (PCA) was applied to simplify the existing dataset from the effect_based assessment and chemical monitoring of the sampling sites to a smaller number of principal components, using OriginPro 10.1 (OriginLab Corporation, Northamptopn, MA, U.S.A.).
#Text=All data were standardized prior to performing the PCA so the mean value for all variables is zero and has a unit variance value.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Hydromorphology.
#Text=The change in habitat structure greatly varied among the streams and indices considered (Fig�2A).
#Text=Restored sections had superior values for five out of six indices at every site, except for Site A, where only three indices showed a positive change.
#Text=Habitat structure scarcely varied at this site, with values ranging from  0.83 to 1.50 and only two indices showing a positive change greater than 1.

#Text=There was no significant two_way interaction between river and restoration status (two_way ANOVA:�F = 2.018,�p = 0.131), however, the pairwise�t�test revealed an overall significant difference between habitat indices at restored and non_restored sites (p � 0.001).
#Text=Thus, overall, the habitat structure could be considerably improved through the measures.
#Text=Figure 2\r(A) Change in hydromorphological indices between non_restored and restored sections within the sampling Sites A (Asphe), B (Bieber), F (Fohnbach), J (Josbach), and W (W�rf).
#Text=Green represents a superior value in the restored section compared to the non_restored one, blue shows a superior value in the non_restored section.
#Text=The different indices are depicted by the numbered points.
#Text=(B) Multimeric index and ecological status class in the different sampling sites.
#Text=The dotted lines depict the threshold values for the ecological status classes bad (red), poor (orange) and moderate (yellow).
#Text=Blue triangles represent non_restored and green circles restored river sections.
#Text=Ecological Quality Class\rThe MMI for restored and non_restored sites was similar in the samples from Sites B, J, and W (Fig�2B).
#Text=Despite this, the two samples from Site J were assigned to different ecological classes, although the MMI differed only slightly.
#Text=In contrast, the MMI of Site A samples differed notably.
#Text=While the restored sample was in the upper range of the poor ecological class, the non_restored sample was in the lower range, bordering on the bad ecological class.
#Text=Site F displayed a distinctly higher MMI in the non_restored sample compared to the restored sample, which was two ecological classes worse.
#Text=Therefore, the species communities do not exhibit a consistent trend toward improved ecological status.
#Text=Details of the MMI calculation and related indices can be found in Table�S2.
#Text=Baseline Toxicity\rThe Microtox assay was applied to assess baseline toxicity in water and sediment samples (Fig�3).
#Text=For water samples, weak baseline toxicity was detected for Sites F_nr (EC50�193 +/- 6.5 REF), A_r (EC50�191 +/- 4.7 REF), and A_nr (EC50�190 +/- 10.3 REF).
#Text=No significant differences (unpaired�t�test) between the non_restored and restored river sections were found.
#Text=The respective sediment samples exhibit baseline toxicity at all 10 sampling sites.
#Text=The highest inhibition was found at Site W_nr (EC50�3.9 +/- 0.3 mg SEQ) and the lowest at Site J_nr (EC5056.0 +/- 12.5 mg SEQ).

#Text=Here, the Sites B_r (p = 0.008), F_r (p = 0.047), and W_r (p = 0.005) showed significantly higher EC50�values and therefore a lower toxicity compared to the non_restored sections (unpaired�t�test).
#Text=Figure 3\rBaseline toxicity in water and sediment samples from the non_restored and restored river sections of sampling Sites A (Asphe), B (Bieber), F (Fohnbach), J (Josbach) and W (W�rf).

#Text=Triangles and circles represent the mean values of half maximal effective concentration (EC50) based on (A) the relative enrichment factor (REF) of the water samples or (B) milligrams sediment equivalents (SEQ) from three independent experiments.
#Text=Nontoxic water samples were set to the nontoxic limit (NTL) of 225 REF.
#Text=The error bars represent +/- SE.
#Text=The asterisks represent significant differences between the non_restored and restored sections of the same stream (unpaired�t�test; *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01).
#Text=Estrogenic Activity\rEstrogenicity was assessed using the YES.
#Text=In all water samples, except at Site J_nr, estrogenic activity above the LOD (0.03 ng/L E2_Eq) was detected (Fig�4A).
#Text=The highest estrogenic activity was found for Site J_r (0.49 ng/L), the lowest for Site F_nr (0.06 ng/L).
#Text=A similar estrogenic activity of 0.13_0.20 ng/L was detected at Sites A, B, and W.

#Text=Sites A_r (p = 0.010), J_r (p < 0.001), and F_r (p < 0.001) showed significant (unpaired�T�test) higher activities, whereas Site B_r showed significant (unpaired�t�test with Welch's correction,�p = 0.007) lower activities compared to the non_restored section.
#Text=The associated sediment samples all showed estrogenic activity above the LOD (0.14 ng/g E2_Eq).
#Text=Here, Site A_nr (2.20 ng/g) revealed the highest and J_r (0.58 ng/g) the lowest activity (Fig�4B).

#Text=Site F_r (unpaired�t�test,�p = 0.029) and W_r (unpaired�T�test,�p < 0.001) showed significantly lower activities, whereas B_r (unpaired�Ttest,�p = 0.010) showed higher activity compared to the non_restored section.

#Text=Figure 4\rEstrogenic activity and dioxin_like activity in water (A, C) and sediment (B, D) samples from the non_restored and restored river sections of sampling Sites A (Asphe), B (Bieber), F (Fohnbach), J (Josbach), and W (W�rf).

#Text=The bars represent the mean estrogenic activity expressed as 17 _estradiol equivalents (E2_Eq) and dioxin_like activity expressed as  _naphthoflavone equivalents ( _NF_Eq) of three independent experiments.
#Text=The error bars represent +/- SE.
#Text=The asterisks represent significant differences between the non_restored and restored sections of the same stream.
#Text=LOD, limit of detection; <LOD, below limit of detection.
#Text=Dioxin_Like Activity.
#Text=The dioxin_like activity was assessed using the YDS.
#Text=All water samples were active above the LOD (0.029  g/L 1� _NF_Eq).
#Text=The exception was sample J_nr (Fig�4C), which also showed no estrogenic activity.
#Text=Site A_r shows the highest dioxin_like activity of 0.13  g/L and the lowest, close to the LOD, was detected for Site J_r (0.033  g/L).
#Text=In water samples, Site A_r (p = 0.001) and B_r (p = 0.001) showed significantly (unpaired�t�test) higher dioxin_like activities compared to the non_restored sections.
#Text=Dioxin_like activities above the LOD (0.04  g/g  _NF_Eq) were found in all sediments (Fig�4D).
#Text=The values ranged from 1.42 to 44.8  g/g  _NF_Eq.

#Text=In sediment samples of Sites B_r (p = 0.001), F_r (p < 0.001), and W_r (p < 0.001) significantly (unpaired�t�test with Welch's correction) lower activities compared to the non_restored section were determined.
#Text=Mutagenicity.
#Text=Mutagenicity was assessed in 16.7_fold enriched extracts of water samples and at 66.7 mg SEQ/mL for sediment samples.
#Text=In water samples, no mutagenic effects were detected with the two�Salmonella�strains YG1041 and YG1042 with and without S9 (data not shown).
#Text=In contrast, 3 out of the 10 analyzed sediment samples were mutagenic in at least one of the Ames assays (Table�S5).
#Text=When using the YG1041 strain, only Site F exhibits mutagenic potential (with and without S9 mix) for both the non_restored and restored sections.

#Text=With the YG1042 strain, however, only Site F_nr was found to be active, with and without S9, while Site B_nr was exclusively active with the YG1042 strain with metabolic activation by the S9 mix.

#Text=Reproductive Toxicity Test With�Potamopyrgus antipodarum\rThe 28_day chronic reproduction test using�Potamopyrgus antipodarum�was conducted to assess the reproductive toxicity of combined water/sediment samples from the study sites.
#Text=No significant differences in mortality compared to the negative control were found at any of the analyzed sites.
#Text=In addition, no significant differences between the non_restored and restored stream sections were found.
#Text=All sampling sites showed an overall low mortality not exceeding 10%.
#Text=The average number of embryos per snail in the control was 29.5 +/- 12.4.

#Text=For Sites A_nr, A_r, F_nr, J_r, and W_r, a statistically significant (Kruskal_Wallis test with Dunn's post hoc test,�p < 0.01) reduced reproduction compared to the control group ranging from 21.1 +/- 8.44 to 25.3 +/- 10.1 was determined.
#Text=In addition, Site W_r (p = 0.005) showed a significant (unpaired�t�test) reduction in embryo counts compared to the non_restored section (Fig�5A).
#Text=Figure 5

#Text=(A) Twenty eight_day chronic reproduction test using�Potamopyrgus antipodarum�in a semi_static water/sediment experiment of sampling A (Asphe), B (Bieber), F (Fohnbach), J (Josbach) and W (W�rf).
#Text=The bars represent mean and standard deviation (SD) of embryo count of six replicates (each with 10 snails).
#Text=Asterisks mark significant differences between the non_restored and restored sections of the same stream (unpaired�t�test, **p < 0.01).

#Text=(B) Fish embryo toxicity of�D. rerio�embryos following exposure to sediment extracts (40 mg SEQ/mL) from the non_restored (nr) and restored (r) river sections of the sampling sites after 96 hours.
#Text=Experiment was performed in two independent replicates (each with 10 embryos).
#Text=Bars represent the mean values of sublethal and lethal effects in percentage (%).
#Text=The error bars represent +/- SE.
#Text=The asterisks represent significant differences between the non_restored and restored sections of the same stream (Fisher's exact test, ***p < 0.001).
#Text=Fourteen_Day Survival Test with�Hyalella azteca\rSediment toxicity was assessed using a 14_day survival test with�Hyalella azteca.
#Text=While three sampling sites had no effect on survival compared to the control group, effects were recorded for the other seven sediments (Table�S6).
#Text=The most toxic sediment was Site F_nr (LC50: 12.8 mg SEQ/mL) followed by B_nr (LC50: 27.4 mg SEQ/mL), causing 100% mortality at the highest tested concentration (130 mg SEQ/mL).
#Text=The lowest toxicity of the seven sediments causing mortality of the test organisms was from Site A_r (LC50: 91.9 mg SEQ/mL).
#Text=Fish Embryo Toxicity With�Danio rerio\rFish embryo toxicity was assessed using the FET.
#Text=The effect incidence resulted from sublethal as well as lethal endpoints cumulated after 96 hpf (Fig�5B).
#Text=A total of five lethal and sublethal effects were observed in the embryos, including coagulation, no blood flow, spinal deformation, yolk sac, and pericardial edema.
#Text=The sediment from Site W_r (90 +/- 14.14%) exhibited the highest effect incidence and the broadest spectrum of effects.
#Text=At all other sites, except F_nr (60.0 +/- 0%), the effect incidence did not exceed 50%.
#Text=Site W_r showed a significant (p < 0.001), 2.5_fold increase in the effect rate compared to the non_restored section.
#Text=Frequency Distribution of Toxicity Responses\rA full range of toxicity results was obtained for water and sediment samples.
#Text=The responses of all bioassays were pooled to determine whether samples from the non_restored or restored sections responded more frequently with significantly higher signals in the assays.

#Text=Bioassay signals were categorized into non_restored and restored sample sites and classified as either not significantly higher (0%) or as a response to up to five (100%) significantly higher signals detected in a test.
#Text=In 4 out of 13 tests, no significant differences were found between the non_restored and restored sections among the studied sites.
#Text=The heat map indicates that non_restored sampling sites exhibited significantly higher activities compared to the restored sites, particularly in the tested sediments (Fig�6).
#Text=Conversely, in restored sections, water samples revealed higher activities in two out of five tests.
#Text=The frequency of higher toxicity responses in samples from the restored sites decreased by 30.8% compared to the non_restored sections.

#Text=Figure 6\rHeatmap showing the responses of water (aq) and sediment (sed) samples in the eight bioassays that gave a significantly higher signal, comparing non_restored and restored stream sections.
#Text=For mutagenicity, those sample sites that were active in the assay were included.

#Text=The scale_bar plots the responses in percentage: yellow = 100% and equivalent to response of up to five detected significantly higher signals in a test.; dark blue = 0%, and equivalent to no significantly higher response; green = response in between.

#Text=PCA for Site Relationships Using Chemical and Toxicity Assessment\rThe detected total concentrations (see Table�S4) of organic substances (pharmaceuticals and pesticides) found in water samples were the highest at Site A_r (3.66  g/L) and lowest at F_nr (0.47  g/L), which in turn had the highest contamination with heavy metals (94.0  g/L).
#Text=In addition, Site F_nr also showed the highest total concentration of PAHs of 5.17  g/g and heavy metals (244.2  g/g) in the sediment samples.
#Text=The PCA plot in Figure�7�represents the relationships between the sites in terms of chemical composition and toxicity responses.

#Text=The chemical composition of the sample sites corresponded to a variance of 82.6% for the first two components (PC1 and PC2), with PC1 accounting for 68.3% of the total variability and PC2 for 21.2%.
#Text=The PC1_axis mainly represented the contamination of pesticides (e.g.

#Text=MCPA, metazachlor, and imidacloprid) and PAHs (e.g. benzo[a]pyrene, fluoranthene, and pyrene), while PC2 was mostly influenced by pharmaceuticals (e.g. carbamazepine, diclofenac, and metoprolol).
#Text=Sample sites that are close to each other are similar in their chemical composition.
#Text=The individual water bodies differ from each other in terms of the substances detected.
#Text=However, in terms of contamination, the PCA indicates that restored river sections do not differ notably from sections that have not been restored.
#Text=Yet, minor differences are perceptible between the river sections of sampling Sites F and B.
#Text=In the PCA with toxicity responses, the first two PCs explained 58.4% of the total variance.

#Text=PC1 (38.8%) was mostly driven by estrogenicity and toxicity to�H. azteca�in sediments, as well as dioxin_like activity in water samples, while PC2 (19.6%) comprised fish embryo toxicity and Nrf2 activity (Fig�S1) in sediments.
#Text=Both the streams and sections within them reveal a wide distribution across PCs.

#Text=Figure 7\rPrincipal component analysis (PCA) using PC1 and PC2 for restored (green circles) and non_restored (blue squares) stream sections of sampling Sites A (Asphe), B (Bieber), F (Fohnbach), J (Josbach), and W (W�rf).
#Text=(A) For chemical composition, standardized PC1 explains 61.3% and standardized PC2 explains 21.2% of variance.
#Text=(B) For toxicities in water (aq) and sediment samples (sed), standardized PC1 explains 38.8% and standardized PC2 explains 19.6% of variance.
#Text=The lengths of the arrows indicate loadings on the principal components.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Hydromorphological stream restoration is often considered a key factor for the recovery of degraded aquatic ecosystems and the achievement of a good ecological status.
#Text=However, there is increasing evidence that restoration measures are a necessary but not a sufficient precondition for the recovery of disturbed aquatic ecosystems (Leps et al�2016).

#Text=With the elimination of this stressor, others, such as inadequate water quality due to pollutants, become more important and may prevent to achieve a good ecological status despite extensive hydromorphological restoration measures (Brettschneider et al�2019; He� et al�2023).
#Text=Therefore, this study focused on identifying the impact of chemical pollution on biodiversity loss in the context of hydromorphological restoration of streams.
#Text=Expectations for such restoration included improved hydromorphological structure, which in turn should have a positive influence on the ecological status of water bodies.

#Text=This was especially encouraged by the extended period of up to 29 years that has passed since the implementation of the restorations, as the impact of restoration on aquatic habitat conditions may increase with the age of the project (Kail et al�2015).
#Text=However, this research highlights a remarkable discrepancy in the results achieved.
#Text=Although the physical habitat quality of the restored stream sections improved across almost all five study sites, no consistent ecological improvements were observed in the restored sections.
#Text=Instead, in the case of the most prominent improvement in habitat structure at a restored site compared to the corresponding non_restored site, a decline was documented.

#Text=Furthermore, good ecological status was not reached in any of our sites, and too few Ephemeroptera, Plecoptera, and Trichoptera taxa were observed compared to the proportion expected in the streams considered.
#Text=This suggests the presence of predominant stressors the restoration measures failed to mitigate.

#Text=These observations are consistent with previous findings (Sundermann et al�2013; Posthuma et al�2020; Lemm et al�2021) and raise critical questions about the effectiveness of restoration efforts in the context of stream ecological health.
#Text=Due to a lack of long_term monitoring the success of restoration measures is often not documented.
#Text=In addition, many restoration projects fail because the restored sections are relatively short (Kail & Hering�2009).

#Text=Although this is only partially the case in our study, as the restored sections were between 1.1 and 3.7 km long, other and frequently overlooked stress factors acting at larger spatial scales, such as catchments and sections extending over several kilometers, can significantly affect the composition of aquatic communities (Kail et al�2015) and are also relevant for the stream studied here.
#Text=Not only negative long_distance, but also neighborhood effects such as pollutant sources, can lead to a downgrading of the ecological status in a structurally less impaired watercourse section.
#Text=Chemical pollution may act as a dominant stressor, masking the effects of habitat improvement thereby preventing recovery of ecological status (Brettschneider et al�2023).

#Text=Using EBMs, ranging from sub_organismic to whole_organism bioassays, we were able to detect the effects of chemical mixtures in water and sediment samples, which can lead to considerable changes in the ecological balance (Straalen�2003).
#Text=Sediments from all sampling sites showed high baseline toxicity as well as high estrogenic and dioxin_like activities.
#Text=Three sediments even showed mutagenic potential, and we also observed embryotoxic effects in�Danio rerio.
#Text=In the chronic test with�Hyalella azteca, an impairment of the survival rate was observed.
#Text=The examined water samples also clearly showed the potential impacts of pollutants on the aquatic environment, although with overall lower activities compared to the sediments.

#Text=Thus, we were able to measure estrogenic activity in all waters except the water sample from J_nr, whose counterpart, the water sample from the restored site, even exceeded the proposed average annual environmental quality standard (AA_EQS) for 17 _estradiol of 0.4 ng/L.
#Text=This is in contrast to the significant decrease in reproduction using native samples in a semi_static combined water/sediment experiment with�Potamopyrgus antipodarum.

#Text=Exposure to estrogen_active samples usually increases the number of embryos in�P. antipodarum, but this effect can be masked if the number of embryos in the control group is already very high or if the stimulation of reproduction by estrogens is antagonized by toxic samples (Sieratowicz et al�2011).

#Text=Yet, the high baseline toxicity, but also the high dioxin_like activities found in the sediment samples could mask estrogenic effects as described also for other species (Hutz�1999; Hutz et al�2014).
#Text=This is also reflected in the chemical analysis of the sediments, which revealed cumulative PAH concentrations of up to 5.17  g/g.

#Text=The detected PAHs fluoranthene, phenanthrene, and pyrene, which are on the list of substances of very high concern due to their persistence, bioaccumulation, and toxicity (ECHA�2024), provided the largest share of these high concentrations.
#Text=This suggests the influence of both domestic and industrial dischargers, as well as atmospheric deposition (Liu et al�2017).
#Text=The chemical analysis of the water samples revealed impairment of water quality by pesticides and pharmaceuticals.
#Text=The AA_EQS for MCPA of 2  g/L (Liess et al�2023) was exceeded at both sections of Site A.

#Text=Additionally, the AA_EQS for imidacloprid of 0.002  g/L (Liess et al�2023) was exceeded by all sites, except for Site F where the neonicotinoid could not be detected above the limit of quantification.
#Text=However, the assessed effects and their differences between water samples of the same stream using EBMs could not be explained by chemical analysis.

#Text=Concentrations found in water grab samples are typically snapshots in time and often underestimate peak concentrations or the pollution load in general (Relyea & Hoverman�2006; Betz_Koch et al�2023).

#Text=Additionally, the biological response to a restoration program may be dominated by brief periods of poor water quality, which are difficult to detect unless monitored at the time of impact (Skinner et al�2008; Weisner et al�2021).
#Text=Therefore, we evaluate an effect_based assessment of watercourses as an essential tool to avoid underestimating the harmful effects on aquatic organisms (De Baat et al�2019).

#Text=Nevertheless, the chemical monitoring showed that the sampling sites are affected by anthropogenic activities like the discharge of treated wastewater, which is also reflected in the estrogenic activity of the water samples.

#Text=Harth et al (2018) demonstrated that small wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) can significantly impact water quality (Steinh�user et al�2022), especially when discharging into smaller watercourses, which often results in low dilution of the treated wastewater.
#Text=In addition, a recent study by Enns et al (2023) showed that there are strong changes in the composition of macrozoobenthic communities between sites upstream and downstream of WWTPs.
#Text=In future, studies are needed to address the influence of the respective WWTPs on the studied sites.
#Text=In our study, PCA with the chemical data showed that differences among streams are generally greater than differences between the non_restored and restored reach within a stream.
#Text=Differences observed at Sites B and F within a watercourse are primarily due to varying pollutant concentrations in sediments.

#Text=The sorption of pollutants in sediments is associated with the content of organic matter (Karickhoff et al�1979; Ahlf & Heise�2007), which differed significantly between the restored and non_restored sections of these sites.
#Text=In contrast, PCA that was used to identify toxicity responses revealed that the effects varied among the rivers and within their respective sections.

#Text=While recent ecotoxicological studies reported an increase in toxicity in the restored river sections (Brettschneider et al�2019), the present findings do not provide conclusive evidence of an increase in toxicity in the restored stream sections.
#Text=Significant differences in effect intensities were observed between the restored and non_restored stream sections, depending on the respective bioassays.
#Text=Here, overall, higher effect activities were assessed for the non_restored sections.

#Text=This difference in toxicity levels may be attributed to the variation in flow velocities and the stony_sandy bed substrate of the studied sites (Ahlf & Heise�2007; Pottgiesser�2018), whereas in Brettschneider et al (2019), the increased toxicity was probably mainly due to the input of fine sediments that alters the water quality of rivers as suspended particles (Lemm & Feld�2017).
#Text=However, whether this higher toxicity is related to the input of fine sediment at the restored river sections or whether there are other causes for these findings remains to be determined.

#Text=The present results indicate that chemical pollution is an important factor that not only limits the success of extensive hydromorphological restoration measures but also prevents it several years after their implementation.
#Text=This highlights the complex interrelationship between chemical pollution and the failure to achieve good ecological status despite hydromorphological improvement.
#Text=Consequently, we would like to emphasize the importance of chemical contamination that hinders the full recovery of aquatic ecosystems after hydromorphological restoration measures.

#Text=The influence and complex interactions of such stressors (Sigmund et al�2023) need to be considered and integrated for the long_term management of surface waters in order to achieve good ecological status.
